text: Never in her wildest dreams did UVic's Kelly Richardson think her work would one day become the backdrop to the epic musical stylings of Metallica.
UFC is returning to Canada with a UFC 289 pay-per-view set for June 10 in Vancouver.
B.C.'s South Coast is going to get drenched this Easter weekend, Environment Canada says.
A transient orca with a "cult following" among whale watchers thanks to a tell-tale dorsal fin has been spotted near Boundary Pass in British Columbia's Gulf Islands.
MISSING YOUTH: Coquitlam RCMP is asking for the public's assistance in locating 15-year-old Daniel Gagnon. Read more: https://buff.ly/3nUmWp7
Start with a small room, limit your session to two hours, find a decluttering buddy and more: experts share six tips to make decluttering more manageable.
B.C. Ferries and Vancouver International Airport (YVR) have issued a series of travel tips ahead of the Easter long weekend, expected to be one of the busiest travel periods of the year.
Grocery chains boost profits by charging different prices for the same stuff — and many Canadians are fed up with it
Police have moved into Vancouver's Downtown Eastside on Wednesday morning as the city prepares to carry out its plan to remove a street encampment from the neighbourhood.

Eight months ago, Metro Vancouver announced plans to buy land on Bowen Island with the intention of turning it into a regional park and campground. Now a series of meetings in the next few weeks will likely decide whether the park goes ahead.
My dad set an example of how to work yourself to death — and how not to. So I quit my job and took his camera across Canada to process my grief, writes Taylor Maavara
Mohnaam Kaur Shergill and Manveer Singh Sihota from Sikh Heritage B.C. discuss the meaning of Khazana, or true wealth, as the theme behind this year's Sikh Heritage Month celebrations.
The Kamloops Autism Program, which helps under-sixes with autism and their families, is set to close in May, leaving many at a loss for support.
Zellers is back in B.C. Shoppers talked about their experiences with the store, as they embraced the nostalgia of the discounted retailer in four locations across the province.

The victim of what RCMP allege was terrorism on a Surrey, B.C., bus on Saturday has returned home from hospital after his throat was slashed in an attack a family member says could have easily killed him.
Jordan Eberle scored and notched an assist Tuesday as the Seattle Kraken came all the way back to beat the Canucks 5-2 in Vanouver.
Four dogs seized from a Clearwater, B.C., breeder that were on the brink of starvation are now ready to be adopted, but the SPCA says they're not for everyone.

The province has announced a new housing plan which will see $12 billion spent over a decade in hopes of building more homes to reduce the housing crisis. B.C. Housing Minister Ravi Kahlon spoke to Anita Bathe about the plan.
Wheelchair Basketball Canada announced on Monday the appointment of Vancouver's Marni Abbott-Peter as head coach of the senior women's national team.
Police in Smithers, B.C., fired shots in an attempt to stop a man driving a large piece of heavy equipment through the community Sunday night, causing extensive damage.

Two B.C. truck drivers took matters into their own hands last month when they stopped a commercial vehicle making the type of unsafe lane change they say could have led to another crash on a stretch of highway that's already killed five people this year.
A fungus causing a disease that has wiped out bat populations across North America has been detected in British Columbia, the province says.

Former premier John Horgan is shifting gears from politics to business and not just any business. In what is drawing mixed reactions, the former premier is joining the board of Elk Valley Resources, a British Columbia coal-producing company.
The University of British Columbia is recommending students access TikTok using a web browser due to security and privacy concerns with the app.

Five families from Egypt claim the CBSA's treatment of recent asylum claimants affiliated with the Freedom and Justice Party is fuelled by "Islamophobia" and information provided by the Egyptian government.
The B.C. government has introduced a multibillion-dollar plan to construct more homes as quickly as possible in an attempt to build its way out of the housing crisis.
New Westminster police say they have seen an alarming spike in sextortion cases targeting men and boys and are warning people to be wary of who they interact with online.
A man who allegedly slashed a man's throat on a transit bus in Surrey, B.C., on Saturday is facing terrorism charges.
Investors are snapping up most of the new properties in the Vancouver area. Lien Yeung breaks down the numbers and figure out what it all means.

Even if you don't realize it, you probably know one or two people with autism who are navigating its challenges in adulthood. This story was first published in 2021. World Autism Day is marked annually on April 2.

Vancouver has stood in for many cities in films and TV series for decades — Seattle, New York, even the fictional Fantasia in the film The NeverEnding Story. But one of its iconic roles began 30 years ago as Washington, D.C., in the series The X-Files.

More than 51,000 registered, psychiatric, and licensed practical nurses in British Columbia have reached a tentative contract with the provincial government, with the nurses' union calling it a "groundbreaking commitment".
With Quebec promising to introduce provincewide regulations on short-term rentals listed on the Airbnb app, the B.C. government says it is working on legislation of its own.
A man was arrested on suspicion of attempted murder after a stabbing on a bus at Fraser Highway and 148 Street in Surrey, B.C., on Saturday morning.

Producers of wines, beers and spirits in B.C. say while they welcome the federal government's decision to cap alcohol excise tax increase at two per cent for the new fiscal year, they would rather have it removed.

If you live in B.C., there’s a good chance your last local election was fought on issues of crime, safety, homelessness and housing the most vulnerable. And there’s a good chance your next provincial election will be too.
A combination of supply chain issues, material shortages and changing demand have resulted in rising prices and long waits for Canadians hoping to purchase a new or used vehicle.

The Royal Canadian Navy (RCN) launched a unique, one-year contract recruiting program Friday which allows rookie sailors to sample a military career before committing to the Canadian Armed Forces (CAF) long-term.

The explosion of emojis on smartphones and social media offers hundreds of alternatives to old-fashioned punctuation. But literary scholar Florence Hazrat argues we could use more exclamation marks in our lives, not fewer.

Officials at Simon Fraser University in Burnaby, B.C., have accepted the return of an honorary degree awarded to Mary Ellen Turpel-Lafond, the former judge and law professor whose claims of Indigenous ancestry have been discredited.

An orca will soon be returned to her home in Puget Sound after being kept in a Miami aquarium for over 50 years. Lolita the whale was captured in 1970, and activists have finally struck a deal for her release. Michelle Ghoussoub tells us more about what's in store for Lolita.

The Transportation Safety Board is highlighting the importance of designated landing areas in harbours that are busy with marine and air traffic as it releases a report on a collision between a float plane and a water taxi in Tofino, B.C.
A joint rally was held at Simon Fraser University in Burnaby today as casual workers fought for better contracts.
Yukon is facing Canada's highest per capita death rate from illicit drugs, and First Nations in the territory say toxic drugs are disproportionately affecting their people.
If you bought a salad bowl for lunch in a compostable cardboard container, that greener choice may have come with a dash of "forever chemicals," a new study suggests.
The Vatican has formally repudiated the Doctrine of Discovery, the theories that legitimized the colonial-era seizure of Indigenous lands and still form the basis of some property law today.
Lolita the orca will soon be swimming in her home waters of Puget Sound in Washington state after more than half a century in captivity.
The federal budget included proposals aimed at improving air travel after a year of chaos at Canada's airports. But advocates are skeptical about the measures.

Two recent negligence findings by B.C. judges follow a long string of malpractice allegations made throughout the career of orthopedic surgeon Dr. Tracy Hicks, while for decades, patients and their families raised concerns.
After 13 months of fighting, the parents of λugʷaləs K'ala'ask Shaw have received a birth certificate that accurately represents the spelling of his name.
Mayor Reid Hamer-Jackson and three city councillors will serve on a special committee that will determine the makeup of standing committees in Kamloops, B.C.

Two Canadian women were crowned 2023 Freeride World Tour champions after the fifth and final event of the season in Verbier, Switzerland, was cancelled on Tuesday due to hazardous weather conditions on the Bec des Rosses mountain course.

The head of a bronze statue of Indian independence leader Mahatma Gandhi has been removed and stolen from the Burnaby, B.C., campus of Simon Fraser University, and police are now searching for evidence of why and how it happened. https://buff.ly/3FZCoXa.

Tuesday’s federal budget included funding to help low-income communities with grocery costs. To discuss its implications, CBC’s Anita Bathe is joined by Ingrid Benavides, a mother of four who is frustrated by increasing food prices.
From groceries to booze, payday loans to plane tickets — here's what the budget means for your wallet.

The B.C. government is discussing public safety in the province after a man was stabbed to death in Vancouver on Sunday evening. CBC’s Justin Mcelroy explains what he heard on Tuesday in the Legislative Assembly during question period.

As the cost of single-room occupancy buildings in Vancouver rises, so do calls for an increase in government action to protect affordable accommodation. CBC’s Joel Ballard reports on some possible fixes.
A councillor from North Saanich, B.C., has resigned after referring to the mayor as "Mr. Hitler'" during a council meeting.

The Archdiocese of Vancouver and St. Thomas More Collegiate school have been named in a class action lawsuit that claims abusive teachers targeted students for decades. CBC’s Dan Burritt explains how those organizations are responding with their own lawsuits.
Five planets – Mars, Uranus, Venus, Mercury and Jupiter – will be lined up in an arc and will be visible on the western horizon just after sunset tonight.
The family of a woman who died in a "catastrophic" car crash caused by an erratic motorcyclist on a major roadway in Surrey, B.C., has been awarded nearly $2.5 million in damages.
Home construction in B.C. will need to rise to unprecedented levels to offset the impact of record immigration on the housing market, the B.C. Real Estate Association said in a new report.

Canadians watching the failure of some large U.S. banks may have questions about their own level of protection from bank calamity. Experts say such events are less likely to occur here, but it's still worth thinking about how deposits are insured.
UPDATE: Chilliwack RCMP says the youth reported missing yesterday has been found and is safe. We've deleted our original tweet that had the youth's name and photo.

Despite previous success in school, Dr. JJ Mráček struggled to find her footing in medicine. Then, just before she finished med school, Mráček got a diagnosis at age 32 that felt like a puzzle being finished: she is autistic.
Simon Becher scored in the eighth minute of stoppage time to give the visiting Vancouver Whitecaps a 1-1 draw with Minnesota United on Saturday night in Saint Paul, Minn.

Brock Boeser scored the go-ahead goal in the second period and the visiting Vancouver Canucks held the Dallas Stars scoreless on four power plays, including one late in the third period, for a 3-1 win Saturday night.

B.C. residents with ties to India’s Punjab region gathered in downtown Vancouver Saturday to wave flags, chant and listen to speeches calling out the India government over its so-called crackdown to arrest a prominent voice in the separatist movement.
A short documentary offers a glimpse into the life of a Surrey, B.C., family during the holy month of Ramadan. This story was first published April 13, 2022.
The Vancouver band Hyaenas celebrates their EP release this weekend.
If passed, the fare increase will begin on Jul 1, 2023.
After more than 50 years of teaching, an Abbotsford potter is retiring, and closing his studio. Herman Venema’s former students say they will remember his legacy as one of creativity and support.

A Vancouver Island fire chief is calling for more workplace support for firefighters following a colleague's death from cancer. Although a claim with WorkSafeBC remains ongoing, the firefighter's death is believed to be work-related.
Chinese Freemasons from across the country are gathering in Vancouver to celebrate 160 years of community and cultural support in Canada.
Stadium fare such as beer, hotdogs, nachos, and popcorn will be sold for $5 at Dawson's Hot Dogs stands at sections 201 and 227 at B.C. Place.
A B.C. photographer who spent four months documenting self-styled preacher Amritpal Singh in India last year says he now fears for the safety of his friends and family in the Punjab region of India.
Vancouver city councillors face two important votes next week, and both concern the future redevelopment of the Broadway corridor. Our municipal affairs reporter Justin McElroy has more.
Members of B.C.'s most northern communities told a forum in Prince George, B.C., this week they need more resources to deal with the impacts of the province's drug crisis.
The British Columbia government says it is permanently doubling the number of subsidized seats for people who want to train to become veterinarians and practice in the province.
A woman dressed as a janitor, complete with a vacuum cleaner mounted on her back, is wanted on suspicion of stealing large amounts of cash from ATMs in banks across B.C.'s Upper Fraser Valley.
The B.C. Search and Rescue Association says calls for help have returned to pre-pandemic levels after a surge in 2021 as more people headed out to enjoy the outdoors at the height of the pandemic.
A man has died after a single-vehicle crash in Surrey, B.C., early Thursday.
IHIT has identified the victim of the March 13 homicide in the Grandview Heights neighbourhood of Surrey, B.C.

Last year's housing starts in Southwest B.C. were the second-highest ever, according to the Chartered Professional Accountants of British Columbia, though the organization and other experts say more are still needed. https://buff.ly/42yz6DX
A study from the University of Alberta and Stanford University has found oil and gas activity likely induced one of the province's largest documented earthquakes that took place last November.
RCMP in Trail, B.C., are warning residents to keep their pets indoors after the poisoning deaths of two dogs.

The Tḱemlúps te Secwépemc First Nation will receive $12.5 million in federal funding to go toward the construction of a new healing centre for the community nearly two years after suspected grave sites were discovered at a former residential school.
A Vancouver police officer suffered spine and head injuries after a car full of "joy-riding teens" hit his unmarked patrol car early Monday morning, according to police.
The Integrated Homicide Investigation Team is appealing to the public for information surrounding Kellen McElwee's disappearance, 15 years after he went missing.
Storage and moving company BigSteelBox Corporation is facing a proposed class action lawsuit after a customer claimed water got into his storage container during the November 2021 floods.
The RCMP in Kelowna, B.C., is investigating an attack at a bus stop where a group of people allegedly teased and then attacked an international student from behind, sending him to the hospital.
Surrey anesthesiologist Dr. Olumuyiwa Bamgbade has been charged with a second count of sexual assault, according to the Delta police department.

Passengers recently scheduled to fly Flair Airlines had difficulty getting compensation after flights were cancelled because some planes were seized. John Gradek, with the school of aviation studies at McGill University, spoke to Dan Burritt about better passenger protections.
An active tuberculosis case has been identified at a B.C. school, prompting the local health authority to notify people who may have been exposed to the disease.
A Vancouver parent has launched a proposed class-action lawsuit against the makers of Fortnite, saying the popular video game is designed to be "as addictive as possible" for children.
The liquidation sales at Nordstrom stores across Canada will begin Tuesday, a spokesperson for the department store chain confirmed in an email to CBC News.
More than 200 bus drivers in the Fraser Valley began a full-scale strike Monday, after negotiations between their union and employer First Transit broke down last week.
Natasha Wodak of Vancouver finished eighth at Sunday's New York City Half Marathon, but more important to the two-time Olympian was how she competed against some of the world's top runners.
Amid ongoing political unrest in Iran, this year's Nowruz celebrations look a little different for some Metro Vancouverites.
Erin Stagg's exhibit at Prince George's Two Rivers Gallery, titled Otipemisewak: The People Who Own Themselves, illustrates stories of the Métis people through the artist's family history.

Tens of thousands of Canadians are joining a call for the Canadian government to help transgender and non-binary people fearing the outcome of anti-LGBTQ legislation gaining ground in the United States and other countries.

Proponents of cryptocurrency mining say the industry's future in Canada is hanging in the balance after several provinces, including B.C., moved to restrict new projects earlier this year in response to concerns about their electricity usage.

A Kelowna music teacher told a provincial court judge he only adjusted a young student's posture while sitting together on a piano bench at his home, and denied ever touching the child in an inappropriate way.

The mayor of Nanaimo says the city is facing a public safety crisis. Yesterday, more than 100 people rallied to express their frustration Jovonne Johnson, founder and executive director of the Risebridge Project, spoke to Michelle Ghoussoub about the situation.
More than 40,000 school support staff in B.C., including education assistants, Indigenous support workers and custodians working in kindergarten to grade 12, are now covered by 69 local agreements.

A controversial custody case has been settled in Hazelton in northern B.C. A judge granted permanent custody to the family of a Gitxsan child whose fate has been up in the air for years. Angela Sterritt has the details.

Kamloops councillors are presenting a united front against what they're calling 'chaotic' and 'unpredictable' behaviour from the mayor, after he restructured committees and removed some councillors from their roles.
Police say they have arrested a man in Nanaimo, B.C., who was allegedly threatening people with a toy bow and arrow that had a syringe with a needle attached to the arrow's tip.

British Columbia Premier David Eby says he's "very troubled'' by allegations of Chinese interference in Vancouver's municipal elections last year and he's asked Canada's intelligence agency for a briefing.
The B.C. Court of Appeal has dismissed an application from Jason Klop, the Fraser Valley naturopath who is banned from producing and selling pills and enemas made from human feces.
Canadians crowded the ski cross World Cup Finals podiums on home snow on Friday, and B.C.'s Reece Howden led the charge with gold in the men's race.
More than 100 people joined a rally in Nanaimo, B.C., Thursday morning to express their frustration with what they describe as escalating crime and a lack of policing in the city.
A 25-year-old snowmobiler is recovering after being rescued Monday from the high backcountry near Crowsnest Pass, Alta.
Legal professionals are rushing to find other places to conduct business and figuring out what has been lost after a major fire gutted the provincial courthouse in Golden, B.C., on Monday.
The saga over the future of Vancouver Island's rail corridor highlights B.C.'s difficulty in creating regional transit.
The B.C. SPCA is warning the public of a Surrey couple selling sick, and sometimes underage, kittens.
Some placer mining cabins in Yukon’s vast backcountry are coming under closer scrutiny by First Nations, who say it’s time to revamp the laws.
The closure of a popular, long-running restaurant that served affordable food is one more blow to Vancouver's Chinatown neighbourhood.

Dozens of passengers flying from Vancouver to New Delhi have been stuck at the Vancouver airport for more than 24 hours with nowhere for many to go after their flight was delayed Monday morning, then cancelled.

With Vancouver among the 16 North American cities sharing hosting duties for an expanded 2026 FIFA World Cup , B.C. Place could potentially host more matches — a prospect the venue's manager describes as "very exciting."

The Canadian Transportation Agency has issued fines to Canada's major airlines for hundreds of violations related to mass flight delays and cancellations last summer and in December — though some passengers and industry experts argue it's not enough.

Advocates working with people who are homeless in B.C. say they're concerned about growing vigilantism after a man was shot while trying to reclaim stolen property from an encampment on Vancouver Island.

A club repeatedly ticketed for flouting COVID-19 rules in B.C. has lost its attempt to get a trial in French. The judge found the club's owner is a monolingual English speaker and that there was no evidence the corporation did any business in French.
A team of doctors is organizing a pop-up Pap test event in Victoria next month following concerns about a backlog in tests and results.
The 2023 Oscars honoured diversity better than in previous years, but some Vancouver entertainers say more needs to be done.
A Nanaimo business owner is in hospital after he was shot trying to recover stolen property from a tent encampment.
B.C. Ferries has launched its first app, which it says travellers can use to check schedules and current conditions, make reservations, and get alerts about service changes.

Seven Vancouver police officers may have abused their authority by using unnecessary force on Myles Gray when he died, and they could face discipline as severe as losing their jobs, an investigation into their conduct has determined.

Seven Vancouver police officers could be facing disciplinary measures in the death of a Sechelt man. The police chief in charge of the investigation found they may have used unnecessary force when dealing with Myles Gray in 2015. Michelle Ghoussoub has more
Putrid, raw sewage has now stopped leaking into the North Shore's Capilano River, though officials say multiple investigations into the spill and any resulting damage are only getting started.
A Vancouver-based musician has received his first Juno nomination for his album Vox.Infold, which was nominated for global music album of the year.

The family of an Indigenous man who died after being arrested by RCMP more than six years ago say they were upset to learn long-awaited court appearances for the officers charged in his death have been put over until later in the spring.
Police say a body has been found inside the remains of a burned tent at an encampment in Vancouver's Downtown Eastside.

The administration of U.S. President Joe Biden said Monday it is approving the major Willow oil project on Alaska's petroleum-rich North Slope, a decision that is drawing condemnation from environmentalists.
Eight skunks found dead in late February in Vancouver and Richmond have tested positive for avian flu.

Under the ground in the B.C. Peace lies Canada’s largest potential source of greenhouse gases. Some want to leave it there. Others say we need the energy. One First Nation is uniquely positioned to play a key role.
What can we do to prepare for the time change Saturday night — and adjust to it? Here's what sleep experts suggest.

The Victoria Vikes squeaked past the University of Prince Edward Island Panthers 93-92 Friday to earn a spot in the U Sports basketball championship semis. Here's a roundup of all the action on Friday.
Internal surveys conducted by the agency responsible for enforcing air passenger protection rules shows a growing level of dissatisfaction with the time it takes to resolve complaints.

Nineteen-year-old singer Lauren Spencer Smith , who was raised on Vancouver Island, is nominated for artist of the year at this year's Juno Awards — the lone early-career artist in the category as she competes against Michael Bublé and the Weeknd.
The whale, believed to be 47, was captured in Icleand and died in captivity at Marineland in Niagara Falls.
Canada Post unveiled its first fleet of battery-electric delivery vehicles in Nanaimo, B.C., on Thursday.
People who witnessed an allegedly deadly confrontation between an off-duty police officer and a young man carrying a skateboard testified in a Nelson, B.C., court room this week.
The cost of the Trans Mountain expansion project has grown to $30.9 billion, according to the Crown corporation behind the pipeline project.

Despite positive measures taken by Canada, Indigenous people continue to face obstacles to fully enjoying their individual and collective human rights in this country, the United Nations special rapporteur on the rights of Indigenous Peoples says.
WestJet has received official approval from the federal government for its proposed takeover of Sunwing, a move that clears the way for the merger to go ahead.
Conflicting accounts over an Indigenous guest who was denied use of a restroom at Vancouver's Hyatt Regency Hotel has Indigenous groups moving to pull business from the hotel.
A Federal Court judge has approved a $2.8 billion settlement agreement between the Canadian government and plaintiffs representing 325 First Nations.

A B.C.-based division of the RCMP is now the subject of a federal probe. The Civilian Review and Complaints Commission is digging into a special unit known as the Community-Industry Response group. Michelle Ghoussoub has more.
Vancouver city council has approved a pilot program that will reduce taxes paid by small, independent businesses, such as restaurants, cafes or artists' studios.

A report from B.C.'s human rights commissioner has confirmed hate-related incidents in the province rose exponentially during the early years of the COVID-19 pandemic, with a 'particularly acute' spike in anti-Asian hate.
B.C. Public Safety Minister Mike Farnworth announced Wednesday that the Alberta Serious Incident Response Team (ASIRT) has been chosen to lead the independent investigation into Prince George RCMP.
A B.C. judge has allowed a class-action lawsuit to proceed involving men from the notorious Mount Cashel orphanage in Newfoundland.
Firefighters rescued a pair of window cleaners stranded multiple storeys up on the uniquely angular Deloitte building at the corner of West Georgia and Homer streets in Vancouver Thursday afternoon.

A new study based on three British Columbia coal mines says the economic benefits from the projects, used to justify their approval during the environmental review process, were "significantly overestimated.''
The province says it plans to invest millions of dollars in a mental health and substance use treatment model that's only been around for a couple of years. Here's how it's expected to work.
B.C. Green Party Leader Sonia Furstenau has tabled legislation that would ban the use of non-disclosure agreements in cases of harassment and discrimination.

With less than three months to go until the closure of a Metro Vancouver assisted living facility for people with mental illness, some residents say they still have no idea where their next home will be.

MISSING PERSON: Surrey RCMP is requesting the public’s assistance with locating 28-year-old Melissa Koks. She is described as an Indigenous female, 5’4, 120 pounds, with long black hair and brown eyes. https://buff.ly/3mvFiMk

The RCMP's federal watchdog agency is opening a probe into the activities and operations of the Community-Industry Response Group, a special unit that polices protests against resource extraction in B.C.
British Columbia Premier David Eby says the federal government needs to reform Canada's bail system now instead of simply talking about it.
Vancouver Island author Michael Christie's book Greenwood is a #CanadaReads finalist this year. He speaks with @allpointswestbc host Jason D'Souza about the book and the competition.
An East Vancouver man captured an unlikely animal encounter when an everyday house cat and a majestic bald eagle had a tense faceoff in a park.

A report from British Columbia's Office of the Auditor General says 61 per cent of the public sector organizations canvassed were victimized by at least one type of fraud in the past year, with "theft of physical assets" the most common.

Aspiring young hockey players in Mongolia were given a helping hand by some Vancouverites as part of Project Mongolia, a hockey donation drive that started in 2015 after a local hockey fan travelled to the country and was inspired to help.

Teams of volunteers are hitting the streets across Metro Vancouver and the Fraser Valley on Wednesday as part of the 2023 homeless count, the first count in three years after pandemic cancellations. Justin McElroy has more.

B.C. is introducing legislation it says will allow action to be taken against people who post intimate images of others online without their consent. This change is welcomed by educators who say the law will be a significant deterrent to future crimes.
Last summer, CBC joined a paleontologist in an expedition to search for marine life fossils dating back more than 500 million years.
The provincial government is putting $200 million toward boosting both the province's food bank system and overall agricultural production and resiliency.
A man from B.C. has been charged in connection with a 2021 attack on a woman who later disappeared from an Ontario home and has now been missing for over a year, police say. https://buff.ly/3JhXemG
Councillors in Surrey plan to use newly allotted provincial funding to reduce the city's proposed 17.5% property tax increase slated for the 2023 civic budget.
Council in Grande Prairie, Alta., has voted to phase out the RCMP in favour of a municipal police force.

As members of Parliament gear up to grill the CEOs of Canada's largest grocery store chains, experts say elected officials should push for more transparency on why supermarkets are making so much money.

The B.C. Court of Appeal has overturned a court decision holding the province liable "in nuisance" after Sunshine Coast residents were forced from their homes by the threat of giant sinkholes in 2018.
Disabled people living in B.C. say the provincial government's move to increase the shelter rate, for those on income and disability assistance, will do little to lift people out of poverty.
Parenting any child is filled with highs and lows. But raising a Black child brings not just immense joy, but unique fears and social issues, writes CBC Parenting Columnist Amy Bell.
Police say a 14-year-old boy from Surrey is missing and has not been seen since Thursday afternoon.

Prep for Pi Day! This March, the CBC Arts logo is looking tasty. In the fun-loving spirit of the occasion, we hired one of the internet's foremost pastry wizards, Vancouver's Jessica Leigh Clark-Bojin, to bake us a logo that's literally sweet as pie.

The use of sensitivity readers has sparked a debate over whether they are censors or provide an important service in promoting inclusivity and combating offensive tropes and racial or sexual stereotypes in published books.

Fancy Bermudez scored a pair of tries as the Canadian women defeated Ireland 24-12 Sunday to put themselves in position for their best result this season at the HSBC Canada Sevens tournament in Vancouver.

Whether it’s an avocado holder or a face cream, there’s no shortage of influencers trying to push mass amounts of expensive products. But the trend of “deinfluencing” is fighting against that fad, and advocates say it could have a positive effect.

Outdoor ice rinks are being replaced by roller rinks as many European cities struggle with their costs and environmental impacts in a warming world. But will Canadian cities face similar decisions? And what can be done to keep outdoor skating alive here?
A Canadian man is being held in connection with the death of a Dawson Creek, B.C. woman at a resort south of Cancun Friday.
A South Surrey third grader has been recognized by the John Hopkins Center for Talented Youth for academic excellence.
The B.C. government has missed the deadline for its review into the possibility of providing air conditioners during heat waves as recommended by a coroners' death review panel last year.
Black Creek, B.C.'s Cam Levins refined his running style after the Tokyo 2020 Olympics and had the race of his life on Sunday to meet the Paris 2024 Olympic standard time.
Three victims of a deadly avalanche in southeastern British Columbia have been identified as German citizens.
These 5 grizzly bears were orphaned as cubs. CBC's 'The Nature of Things' followed them for a year to see if they could survive in the wild.

A cyberattack group says it has released data from Canadian retailer Indigo after the company refused to pay a ransom, but that data did not actually appear on the LockBit 3.0 forums as promised after a deadline passed.
Vancouver has confirmed that it is walking away from its years-long commitment to pay workers a living wage, following a vote in a council meeting that was closed to the public.
Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says he is "as surprised as'' British Columbia Premier David Eby after a firm received Health Canada licence amendments to produce and sell cocaine.
Dozens of B.C. organizations, advocates and academics have joined forces with an urgent plea for the provincial government to legislate pay equity and close the gender gap.
After rising for two weeks, the number of patients in British Columbia hospitals with COVID-19 dipped slightly, the B.C. Centre for Disease Control reported Thursday.
The Coquithalla Highway is closed in both directions between Hope and Merrit due to heavy congestion and extreme winter weather, according to DriveBC.
Two nurses in B.C.'s Interior have been temporarily suspended from practice after admitting to inappropriate sexual conduct on the job.
Bed Bath & Beyond is set to close its Canadian stores sometime in April, following liquidation sales, but customer gift cards are set to expire on March 9.

Crews in Prince George, B.C., are still digging parts of the city out of the snow, after more than 30 centimetres fell in 24 hours near the end of February, hitting the monthly average in a single day.
A former "Dances With Wolves" actor pleaded not guilty Wednesday to state charges that he sexually abused Indigenous women and girls for a decade in Nevada.
RCMP confirmed at least one person has died and several seriously injured following an avalanche on Wednesday.

The federal health minister is pushing back against claims that he interfered with the work of Canada's pharmaceutical pricing agency by asking it to delay reforms intended to bring down the price of patented drugs.
The British Columbia government is investing millions to upgrade the 911 calling system, allowing for location tracking of callers and texting during emergencies.

Free contraception is coming to B.C. next month as part of this year’s provincial budget, and the change is being applauded by many. CBC’s Anita Bathe spoke to Surrey high school student Sophie Choong who has been campaigning for free birth control with AccessBC.
British Columbia is soon to become the first jurisdiction in Canada to make prescription birth control free to its residents. Here's what you need to know — from what's covered to who's covered.
The City of Vancouver approved its budget on Tuesday, and it’s pushing an already record tax rate even higher. As Justin McElroy explains, it's happening in cities across B.C.
